newsitem.title: ROMANIA: Romania's BRD commercial bank raises deposit rates.
newsitem.headline: Romania's BRD commercial bank raises deposit rates.

text.p: Romanian state-run bank Banca Romana pentru Dezvoltare SA (BRD) increased rates on leu deposits, in line with an upward trend in interest rates following central bank moves to tighten monetary policies.
The BRD rate on individuals' sight deposits rose to an annual 18 percent starting Tuesday from a previous 15 percent, a bank statement said.
It said its one-month rate had gone up by eight percentage points to 51 percent. One-year deposits would pay 59 percent, up from 52.
The central bank raised its discount and one-week rates earlier this month to calm soaring inflation.
Year-on-year inflation surged to 56.9 percent in 1996 from 27.8 percent in 1995, nearly triple the 20 percent agreed with the International Monetary Fund.

Economists fear inflation will quicken further this month after the new centrist coalition government, which took office after last November's elections, doubled fuel prices to bring them to world levels in line with IMF recommendations.
The Fund and the World Bank withheld loan tranches for Romania last year over slow reforms. Both institutions are now in Bucharest for talks on renewed loans.
